conclusion: Use Faraday's Law of Electromagnetic Induction to find the magnitude of the induced EMF in the rectangular coil.
The formula for the induced EMF in a rotating coil in a uniform magnetic field is given by: \( \mathcal{E} = n \cdot B \cdot A \cdot \omega \cdot \sin(\omega t) \).
Explanation of variables: \( n \) is the number of turns, \( B \) is the magnetic induction intensity, \( A \) is the area, \( \omega \) is the angular velocity, and \( t \) is the time.
At \( t = 0 \), the coil is perpendicular to the magnetic field lines, making \( \sin(\omega t) = 1 \).
The maximum induced EMF, \( \mathcal{E}_{\text{max}} \), can be calculated using \( \mathcal{E}_{\text{max}} = n \cdot B \cdot A \cdot \omega \).
Calculate the area of the coil: \( A = l_{AB} \times l_{BC} = 0.2 \times 0.5 = 0.1 \text{ m}^2 \).
Substitute the given values into the formula: \( n = 100, B = 0.1 \text{ T}, A = 0.1 \text{ m}^2, \omega = 100\pi \text{ rad/s} \).
The magnitude of the induced EMF in the coil is approximately \( 314.16 \text{ V} \).
